questions.text: Which of the following is a pure opioid antagonist?
questions.solution:
Both naloxone and naltrexone are pure opioid antagonists. 

Nalorphine is an agonist-antagonist. It has antagonistic activity at the mu receptor and additional agonistic activity at the kappa receptor.

Note: Nalmefene is sometimes classified as a pure antagonist but it has additional kappa receptor partial agonist activity.

Related Pearl: Pure opioid antagonists

Naloxone: short-acting opioid antagonist with duration of action of 1-2 hours. Used in opioid overdose and respiratory depression in newborns due to perinatal opioid use.

Naltrexone: long-acting opioid antagonist with effects lasting till 48 hours. Used for prevention of relapse in opioid addiction treatment. It is associated with hepatotoxicity. It does not suppress craving in opioid addiction but suppresses craving in chronic alcoholics.

Nalmefene: long-acting opioid antagonist with a half-life of 8-10 hours administered intravenously. Used in opioid overdose like naloxone.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about opioid antagonists?

choices.text: Naloxone is a short acting drug
Nalmefene can be used for treatment of opioid overdose
Nalmefene is shorter acting than naloxone

questions.solution:
Nalmefene is longer-acting (not shorter-acting) than naloxone.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about naltrexone?

choices.text: Is used in the treatment of alcohol dependence

questions.solution:
Naltrexone is more potent than naloxone.

questions.text: A patient is on chronic opioid therapy for pain management. He would not develop tolerance against which of the following actions of opioids?
questions.solution:
Tolerance is developed to all the above actions of opioids except for miosis.

Exceptions to opioid tolerance (3C's):

  • Constricted pupil (miosis)
  • Constipation
  • Convulsions

questions.text: An elderly man, who is on chronic morphine therapy for pain relief, visits your clinic with complaints of not passing stools for the last 4 days. Which of the following drugs is best suited to treat his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture points towards opioid-induced constipation. Methylnaltrexone, an opioid antagonist with predominant peripheral action is best suited for treating opioid-induced constipation.

Methylnaltrexone is a peripheral µ receptor antagonist. It was introduced in the treatment of opioid-induced constipation refractory to other measures.

It is a quaternary ammonium compound and hence cannot cross the blood-brain barrier. It can reverse the effects mediated by peripheral opioid receptors and spares CNS effects like analgesia.

The peripherally acting opioid antagonists include:

  • Methylnaltrexone
  • Naloxegol
  • Naldemedine
  • Alvimopan

questions.text: Which of the following is not an antagonist at Âµ receptor?
questions.solution:
Naltrindole is a new non-peptide drug which has a selective antagonistic activity on the δ receptor. This drug is still in the trial phase and is not yet in use.

Option B: Naloxone is considered a pure opioid receptor antagonist but at high doses, it is found to have partial agonistic activity on the μ- and κ-opioid receptors.

Option C: Nalbuphine is an agonist-antagonist opioid which acts as an antagonist at the μ receptor and an agonist at the κ receptor.

Option D: Naltrexone is a μ-, δ- and κ-opioid receptor antagonist.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presented to the casualty with slurred speech and shallow breathing. On examination, you find he has bradycardia, hypotension, and pin-point pupils. Which drug will you choose to treat him?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of opioid overdose. Naloxone is the drug of choice for opioid overdose.

Opioid overdose symptoms:

  • Triad of coma, respiratory depression, and pinpoint pupils (miosis)
  • Hypotension, bradycardia
  • Shallow breathing
  • Hypothermia

Naloxone is also used for reversing neonatal asphyxia due to opioid usage in labor. Naloxone is a pure opioid antagonist which reverses all effects except sedation.

Note: Naloxone is contraindicated in infants born to mothers with opiate addiction as it may precipitate acute neonatal withdrawal with seizures.

questions.text: A college student who is addicted to intravenous heroin abruptly stopped abusing the drug during exams. Which of the following would you not expect as a part of withdrawal?
questions.solution:
Diarrhea (not constipation) is seen in opioid withdrawal.

Opioid withdrawal symptoms (mnemonic- O MY WITHDRAWALS):

  • Mydriasis
  • Yawning
  • Weakness
  • Insomnia, irritability
  • Tremors, tachycardia
  • Hypertension, hyperactive
  • Diarrhea
  • Rhinorrhoea
  • Apnoeic attacks
  • Weight loss
  • Anxiety
  • Lacrimation
  • Sweating

questions.text: An elderly woman who was dependent on morphine for her palliative care recently got switched to another opioid medication. A few days later she started developing withdrawal symptoms. Which of the following opioids would have been prescribed to her?
questions.solution:
Pentazocine can precipitate withdrawal symptoms in opioid-dependent patients.

It acts as a weak antagonist or partial agonist at mu-opioid receptors which may precipitate withdrawal symptoms.

Options A, C, and D: Pethidine, morphine, and methadone are pure agonists at mu-receptors and do not precipitate withdrawal symptoms.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man with a history of heroin addiction is referred to a rehabilitation center. Which of the following would you use as a substitute drug for maintenance therapy?
questions.solution:
Methadone is used as a substitute drug for the maintenance therapy of opioid (heroin) dependence. This is because of its good oral bioavailability and long half-life. 

Methadone is substituted for opioids during detoxification to avoid withdrawal symptoms. Once stabilized, the dose is gradually reduced and the drug is stopped slowly over days. 

Due to its long half-life and accumulation in tissues, discontinuing the drug still results in low concentrations of the drug in plasma resulting in protracted withdrawal symptoms.

Maintainance therapy for opioid dependence:

  • Long-acting opioid agonist - a safer substitute like methadone is given in a supervised manner to prevent withdrawal symptoms
  • Partial agonist - buprenorphine can also be used
  • Clonidine, lofexidine - alpha-2 agonists act as sympatholytic and reduce the withdrawal symptoms
  • LAAM(L-Alpha-Acetyl-Methadol) - opioid agonist which reduces craving
  • Naltrexone - is an opioid antagonist used in maintenance therapy to prevent relapses

questions.text: A physician prescribes naltrexone to a patient undergoing treatment for opioid addiction. What is the function of this drug in opioid addiction?
questions.solution:
Naltrexone is used for the prevention of relapse in opioid addiction.

It is given only after initial opioid detoxification. The patient should be opioid-free for 7-10 days and have a negative naloxone challenge (no withdrawal after naloxone administration).

Naltrexone is a pure opioid antagonist which is more potent than naloxone. It is orally active and has a long duration of action which makes it suitable for opioid blockade therapy in post-addicts.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about the use of naltrexone in the treatment of opioid addiction?

choices.text: Discontinuation of naltrexone does not cause withdrawal symptoms
It satisfies craving in opioid addicts
It blocks the effects of opioids if they are used
It is administered only when the patient has completed detoxification from opioids

questions.solution:
Naltrexone does not satisfy the craving of opioid addicts. It is an opioid antagonist with a high affinity for μ opioid receptors. 

Naltrexone does not suppress craving in opioid addiction but it suppresses craving in chronic alcoholics.

Opioid agonists such as methadone and buprenorphine suppress craving and withdrawal symptoms and are therefore used in the first stage of detoxification in opioid addiction.

Option A: Discontinuation of naltrexone ingestion has no negative physical consequences, as opposed to discontinuation of agonist maintenance therapies, which results in the emergence of opioid withdrawal symptoms. This is a major reason for noncompliance and treatment failure.

Option C: It blocks the effects of opioids and prevents the user from experiencing subjective symptoms of opioid intoxication such as euphoria on subsequent use. As the user does not experience these symptoms, he does not develop a craving for the substance. Thus, naltrexone prevents relapse.

Option D: It is only administered when the patient has completed a medically supervised detoxification from opioids because it can cause immediate withdrawal symptoms.

questions.text: You are treating a 31-year-old man with heroin dependence. Which of the following drugs would you not prescribe to him?
questions.solution:
Disulfiram cannot be used to treat heroin dependence.

It is an aldehyde dehydrogenase inhibitor used in the maintenance therapy of alcohol abstinence.

Maintainance therapy for opioid dependence:

  • Long-acting opioid agonist - a safer substitute like methadone is given in a supervised manner to prevent withdrawal symptoms
  • Partial agonist - buprenorphine can also be used
  • Clonidine, lofexidine - alpha-2 agonists act as sympatholytic and reduce the withdrawal symptoms
  • LAAM(L-Alpha-Acetyl-Methadol) - opioid agonist which reduces craving
  • Naltrexone - is an opioid antagonist used in maintenance therapy to prevent relapses
